#Text=UK media apparently conflict with Scots law in Mikaeel Kular case
#Text=Saturday , January 18 , 2014
#Text=Media organisations in the United Kingdom have been focused on Edinburgh this week following the disappearance of three-year-old Mikaeel Kular .
#Text=With the discovery of a body today
#Text=Wikinews has found evidence suggesting media has been caught out by Scottish contempt of court law .
#Text=BBC coverage of the matter , censored by our correspondent who is in Scotland .
#Text=The censored areas identify the detained person and include an image of them .
#Text=Image : BBC .
#Text=The BBC College of Journalism notes the differences .
#Text=" ... dock identification is a more important part of court procedure [ in Scotland ] and therefore pictures of the accused cannot be published until the trial is over .

#Text=Channel 4 's Producer 's Handbook notes  the law has tended to be interpreted more strictly in Scotland " but does not advise on how so .

column1: #Text=Images of arrested persons in high-profile cases are often published in cases south of the border .
#Text=Channel 4 is also amongst organisations to have named the detained person and put an image of them online .
#Text=Police announced last night that a body believed to be the missing child had been found in Fife and that an individual had been detained .
#Text=The boy had been missing since Thursday morning although there was a possible sighting of him then .
#Text=Hundreds of volunteers have assisted police searching the Scottish capital for the boy .
#Text=Wikinews has also found the following organisations publishing material that may prove problematic as the case becomes a major media story .
#Text=The Guardian featured this box on their homepage today , naming the detained person .
#Text=Image : The Guardian .
#Text=Sky News named the person in question and published a photo both online and on national TV
#Text=The Guardian placed the person 's name on their website
#Text=The Telegraph placed a photo and name on their website
#Text=The Independent placed a photo and name on their website , later removing the photo from their article but not their homepage
#Text=The Daily Mail published online a profile of the person including several photos , and noted the person was friends with the victim of a gun murder in Edinburgh
#Text=The Mirror published six articles on the case online , including a timeline and two live blogs .
#Text=All named the detained person .
#Text=Metro identified the person on their website but did not publish a photo
#Text=The Evening Standard published the name and a photo on their website
#Text=The Daily Star reported the person had been " immediately detained " and placed a photo on their website
#Text=The Sun , which had offered a £ 25,000 reward , named the person in an article on their website that included a photo .
#Text=Both the photo and identifying information appeared on their homepage .
#Text=Manchester Evening News placed a live blog on their website naming the person

#Text=The Daily Mail have placed the story prominently on their homepage , with the material behind the boxes including a photograph , a descriptive link to a profile , and the name of the detained person .
#Text=Image : The Daily Mail .
#Text=Some Scottish publications have also been publishing similar material .
#Text=The Scotsman published an article and video identifying the person on their website
#Text=The Herald noted police would not identify the person but nonetheless placed their name and a photograph online
#Text=The articles rank amongst the most-read items on many of the news websites .
#Text=Unlike in England and Wales , where only the Attorney General can prosecute contempt of this sort , in Scotland the media organisations can be charged by an accused person .
#Text=Wikinewsies in Scotland have noted remarks made about the named person 's alleged wrongdoing on public transport and Facebook , suggesting widespread knowledge of their identity .
#Text=Several of the organisations involved are no stranger to being prosecuted for contempt over cases in neighbouring England .
#Text=In 2011 The Sun and The Daily Mail were successfully prosecuted for contempt by Attorney General Dominic Grieve after they published a photo of a murder defendant posing with a gun .
#Text=The case did not involve firearms and Grieve spoke of " seriously impeded or prejudiced " proceedings if any jurors saw the photos .
#Text=The trial was not stopped as the photo was removed from circulation before the jury saw it and the defendant was found guilty .
#Text=In 2011 The Sun and Mirror were fined for reporting negatively about an arrested suspect in the high-profile Jo Yeates murder investigation .
#Text=Chris Jeffries , landlord of the victim , was subsequently released from police custody and proved to be entirely innocent .
#Text=Jeffries also pursued libel action against a number of publications .
#Text=Politicians subsequently considered a law banning the naming of arrested persons who have not been charged throughout the UK as a direct result of this case .
#Text=The Daily Mail and Mirror were back in court the next year for their coverage of a trial involving serial killer Levi Bellfield .
#Text=The two papers were again fined after Dominic Grieve told the High Court in London of an " avalanche " of " seriously prejudicial " stories .
#Text=The papers published their stories after Bellfield was convicted of abducting and murdering schoolgirl Milly Dowler .
#Text=The trial was not yet over , however , as the jury was still considering an additional charge relating to another alleged attempted abduction .
#Text=That charge was dropped because of news coverage .
#Text=Wikinews is awaiting comment from several prominent Scottish professors of law on the issues raised by this article .
